Credits.Story By: RICK CLEVELAND, LAWRENCE O'DONNELL JR. & PATRICK CADDELL

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: 1:30 A.M. Bartlet, sitting in a chair in the middle of his office, is talking to Josh. Josh looks very sleepy, but Bartlet still continues to speak.

Dialogues.Line: Yellowstone, established by an act signed by Ulysses S. Grant was the nation's first national park - March 1, 1872.
[stands] It's getting late, sir. I was wondering, are we through for the evening?
[smiling] Well, we're through with work, Josh, but this part's fun.
The part where I get you to sit down, and teach you a little something.
Perhaps, if you get into bed and...
I'm a national park buff, Josh.
[smiling] I said I'm a national park buff. I bet you didn't know that about me.
Well, I didn't know that about you, sir, but I'm certainly not surprised.
You're... quite a nerd, Mr. President.
I assume that was said with all due respect.

[gets up and sits near Josh] Is it nerd-like to know that Everglades National Park is the largest remaining subtropical wilderness in the continental United States, AND has extensive mangrove forests?
Just a little bit. Yes, sir.
There are 54 national parks in the country, Josh.
Please tell me you haven't been to all of them.
I HAVE been to all of them. I should show you my slide collection.
[counting with fingers] Grand Canyon, Bryce Canyon, Badlands, Capitol Reef, Acadia, which is so often overlooked...
You should certainly feel free to keep talking, but I need to go home so I could be back in my office in four hours.
See, the thing is, I can't leave without your permission.

Petrified Forests, North Cascades, Joshua Tree, Shenandoah National Park, right here in Virginia! [bangs hand on couch] We should organize a staff field trip to Shenandoah. What do you think? [walks to his desk and writes a note]
Good a place as any to dump your body.
Did I say that out loud?
See, and I was gonna let you go home.
We're gonna talk about Yosemite. He sits back on his chair. Josh rests back his head on his chair.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. HOTEL RESTAURANT - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is having breakfast with Mallory. They just finished drinking coffee when a waiter approaches.

Dialogues.Line: Thanks, Tony. Hang on. The waiter puts the bill on the table and stands beside them to wait for the payment. Leo picks up the bill and puts on his glasses.
Oh, let me pay for it.
Yeah, but this is my hotel.
How much does a cup of coffee cost here, Tony?
[to Mallory] You want to pay the check?
[puts his credit card on the bill and gives it to the waiter] Thanks.
Yes... You haven't told me about your mom.
Tell me about her. Congressman Matt Skinner approaches their table.
Thank you. You know my daughter, Mallory.
Of course. Hi, how are you?
Thank you. You haven't told me about your mother.
What do you want to know?
Is she... [thinks] I don't know. Tell me anything.
You could call her, and ask her how she's doing, you know?
Yeah, or I could just ask you.
You could, but clearly, asking me wouldn't do any good.
I'm beginning to get that impression. [takes something out of his jacket pocket]
Opera tickets. It's our subscription night.
And while you were asking her if she wanted opera tickets you couldn't just ask her how she's doing?
I had an opportunity to give you up for adoption, you know.
Too late. Leo starts to pack up and get ready for work.
Please, Mallory. You were... I don't know, you were smirking...
You were doing it with your voice.
Father... you've gone round the bend.
[looks at Mallory] You want the tickets?
You want to walk me back to work?
Sure. Leo looks at his daughter and smiles.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is talking to Mrs. Landingham.

Dialogues.Line: They were talking till two in the morning?
I'd imagine the President was doing the lion's share of the talking. Behind C.J., the door to the Oval Office quickly opens as Bartlet comes out looking very happy.
Were you and Josh talking 'til two in the morning about national parks?
Ooh, C.J., Everglades National Park is one of the biggest...
Right. I got to take this call so I can gloat about the Banking Bill.
Be talking about this C.J. This is the story!
[stops] Oh, incidentally, the California Live Oak is the...
Yes, sir. Bartlet steps into the Oval Office and closes the door. Mrs. Landingham smiles at C.J.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Vice President Hoynes steps into the Roosevelt Room full of cabinet officers. He starts the cabinet meeting.

Dialogues.Line: [walks around the table to his seat] Let's take our seats. The President is gonna be a couple minutes late. He wanted me to get things started. [sits] I should begin by welcoming all of you to our third cabinet meeting, our first in six months. And I know the President would want me to point out that this meetings are for us a unique opportunity to come together and exchange ideas and to discuss our goals for the future. Surely, our first goal has to be finding a way to work with Congress. We need to reach out to the House and to the... The cabinet members swiftly stood up when they see Bartlet enter.
Mr. President. Bartlet looks around at his cabinet members and walks around the room.

This is the saddest looking cabinet I have ever... look at this. I have an agriculture secretary who hasn't eaten a vegetable in his life. Everybody sit down. You're freaking me out. Good morning, Leo.
Good morning, sir. Bartlet walks to the woman at the end of the room.
Mildred? I'm Josiah Bartlet. I'm the President of the United States.
The Vice President. [reading from notes] 'Let's take our seats. The President's gonna be a few minutes late...'
Uh, would you skip down, please?
Yes, sir. 'I know the President would want me to point out that these meetings are unique opportunities for us to...'
Actually, I find these meeting to be a fairly mind-numbing experience, but Leo assures me that they are Constitutionally required, so let's get it over with. Proceed, Mildred.
'Surely, our first goal should be finding a way to work with Congress...'
Our first goal should be finding a way to work with Congress?
You don't think our first goal is should be finding a way to best serve the American People?
I didn't say that Mr. President.
Really? Let's have a look. [takes out his glasses and reads Mildred's notes] Yeah, that's what it says right here. Would you like Mildred to read it back again?
Good. Now let's get to work.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby and Sam are going through a bunch of papers that they have written.

Dialogues.Line: My writing's been a little flat lately.
Well, you did the best you could.
No, I didn't. I can do better than this.
I can do better than this.
Are you saying I can't do better than this?
I'm saying you're fine, and I'm flat.
[passes by and stops] What's going on?
We're having difficulty locating our talent.
Are you hearing anything about the Banking Bill?
I don't know. I'm hearing some stuff.
Yeah. I'm having lunch with Crane.
Alright... It couldn't have gone far, right?
Somewhere in this building... is our talent.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Danny visits C.J. in her office. C.J. is working on her computer.

Dialogues.Line: How is it my staff just lets you walk in here?
Go figure. C.J. walks out of his office and Danny follows her into the HALLWAY.
I heard the President roughed up Hoynes in the cabinet meeting.
Then you can read about it in my newspaper. C.J. and Danny cut through the corner of the Communications Office.
Hey, you want to have dinner with me tonight?
No. Tell me more about this.
That's what I thought. And you won't have dinner with me.
I'm a very good-looking guy, C.J. I mention that because that's something people notice about me right away.
I like seafood. I like all food.
I should also mention I 'm a lively conversationalist. I'm very good at kayaking. I can kayak.
My point is, I can teach you.
No, you idiot, I mean, I can't have dinner.
Okay. C.J. takes one last look at Danny as he leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Reporters, including Danny, surround Hoynes in the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: So, let me tell you something. Yesterday morning about ten o'clock, these two guys, as a joke, posted some false information on a website about this tiny start-up company, and it's stock started shooting up. By 2:30 in the afternoon, the hoax had been uncovered and the stock had adjusted itself. But by the end of the day this company, which neither you or I or the Secretary of Commerce has ever heard of, closed out as the twelfth highest traded issue on the Nasdaq index. This just in: the Internet is not a fad.
Hey, thank you all. Hoynes starts to walk with his staff. Danny tries to ask him a question.
Anything you want to talk about?
Anything I want to talk about?
Well, you know, now that you talk about it, I've been having this recurring dream about killing you.
What do you think that means?
I heard some things about the meeting.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. comes from behind Sam, who is walking to his office.

Dialogues.Line: You heard anything about the cabinet meeting this morning?
Like the President took Hoynes out for a ride?
I don't know. They walk inside the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE. Sam and C.J. see Mallory waiting in front of Sam's office.
Hey, Mallory. [to Sam] Hey, let me know if you hear anything. [leaves]
Pretty good. I just had breakfast with my father and I walked with him back.
Can I talk to you for a second?
Sure. Mallory walks into SAM'S OFFICE. Sam follows her.
Do you by any chance like opera?
You mean to go and watch and listen to?
Because, as it happens, I have two tickets to the Beijing Opera this evening at the Kennedy Center. My father's seats.
[smiling] You're asking me out on a date.
No, I'm asking you if you'd like to go together with me to see an internationally renowned opera company perform a work indigenous to its culture.
Right, and in what way will it distinguish itself from a date?
There will be, under no circumstances, sex for you at the end of the evening.

Well, uh... like most people, I'm an absolute nut for Chinese opera. The Chinese being known the world over for their soaring and romantic melodies, and what with your guarantee that there won't be sex, I don't see how I could say no.
Good, then. I'll come by and get you in about 7:30.
Yeah. Mallory heads for the door.
Hey, you know what's good about this? If you hadn't come along with your offer of Chinese opera and no sex, all I'd be doing later is watching Monday night football, so this works out great for me.
Yes, indeed. Mallory leaves. Sam smiles and walks to his desk.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and C.J. are sitting on each of Leo's chairs in front of his table. They are waiting for Leo to come. Margaret comes in and takes something from Leo's file cabinet.

Dialogues.Line: Leo will be in in a minute.
Thank you. Silence fills the room. C.J. asks Sam a question.
Somebody go first. Sam and C.J. look at each other. C.J. decides to go first.
Danny Concannon said that he heard that the President and Hoynes had a...
Then why is Danny asking me about it?
You think he's gonna tell me?
What do you want me to do?
You're a real details man aren't you, Leo?
Deal with it. C.J. stands up and leaves the office. Leo sits down, rummaging through papers, and without looking at Sam...
Mallory had an extra ticket to the opera for tonight and she asked me if I'd like to go.
[looks up swiftly and takes off his glasses] Mallory, my daughter...
...to go to the opera using the tickets that used to belong to me and Mallory's mother...
...the woman who used to be my wife?
Leo, for whatever it's worth, she's made it very clear we won't be doing anything tonight you'd have a problem with.
Why don't we stay away from that?
Jenny and I aren't using them. Somebody should.
Yeah. Leo arranges the papers in his table. He pauses for a second and thinks.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. MURAL ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: The room is flooded with camera flashes as Hoynes talks to a number of important people.

Dialogues.Line: Nitrogen and hydrogen, ladies and gentlemen, nitrogen and hydrogen. Now, Dick Brenner says we send a Saturn V rocket with a liquid-hydrogen payload or we can put a man on Mars for 25 billion dollars? That's a steal at twice the price.
Once you've landed him, where are you gonna get the hydrogen to get him back?
Well, Mars is built made out of Nitrogen so the best thing to do is build ourselves a gas station.
Yeah, we're done here. Maybe we should take an earth science course again. Thank you, all.
Sir, C.J. Cregg asked for a minute.
Yeah, I could have seen that coming. Hoynes and his staff walk out of the Mural Room into the HALLWAY. C.J. tries to talk to him.
Yeah, whoever Danny's been talking to, it wasn't me, C.J.
I'd just want to keep it from becoming a story.
And I'd like to keep it that way, sir.
What can I do for you?
What happened at the cabinet meeting and how did Danny find out about it?

[stops walking] Nothing happened at the cabinet meeting and I have no idea how Danny found out about it. Moreover, the implication that I leaked privileged information is stupid as it is insulting. And I'd like to remind you, that whatever regard you may hold from me personally, you are addressing the office of the Vice President.
Good. [to staff] Let's go. C.J. stands still as Hoynes walks away with his staff.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby knocks on the door of Sam's open office.

Dialogues.Line: Banking Bill's gonna pass the house, let's prepare a statement.
He said it was in the bag. Toby and Sam step inside TOBY'S OFFICE. Josh follows them.
I just got done with Crane.
Big Sky Federal Reserve, Sam. They want to strip mine the length and breadth of Montana.
Please, this isn't about the environment. It's about retribution.
Yeah, no kidding. There were a few moments of silence until they realized what they should do.
We need to see the President.
Yeah, we need to see the President.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is having her usual briefing. Danny is sitting with other reporters.

Dialogues.Line: I am reluctant to characterize it other than to say the President is interested in what the practical effects of the policy would be.
But in all, you'd say the White House is optimistic about the chances of passage through the House of the Banking Bill?
You're not concerned about the attachment of the land use rider?
I said The White House isn't concerned about the attachment of the land-use rider?
[slowly] That's being worked out, and I can go into more detail later.
Any chance you could go into more detail now?
I could, but then you'd have no reason to talk to me later.
I'll do that later this afternoon. Thank you everybody. C.J. walks out of the briefing room, and steps to the HALLWAY. Danny follows her. Bonnie passes by.
Bonnie, find Toby for me, would you?
Sure. Danny surprises C.J. when he speaks from behind her.
The land-use rider was a bit of shock for you, huh?
Danny, do you see that this is a restricted area? There are signs posted.
There are usually signs posted. They stop in front of many hardworking White House aides working hard in their bullpen.
Hey you guys, you don't mind me here do you?
Danny... The two start to walk again.
I'm saying it looked like someone took your legs behind you. Speaking of legs. [looks at C.J.'s legs]

First of all, you're wrong. Second of all, shut up. Third, I went to Hoynes about your thing and it wasn't him who talked to you and I believe him, and now he's really pissed at me, and he's right, and fourth... shut up again.
It wasn't Hoynes who talked to me.
Yes, well, I know that now.
I enjoy movies. I enjoy music. I'm not wild about ice-skating, but, what the hell, I'll do it. They stop again in front of the White House aides.
[to C.J.] A day's work for a day's pay. C.J. walks into the bullpen, where Bonnie is on the phone.
Should I tell him you're coming?
No I'd like to keep it a surprise.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Leo walk.

Dialogues.Line: What happened? They step into LEO'S OFFICE.
Eaton and Broderick got a land-use rider to the conference report.
Eaton and Broderick attached a land-use rider? They finally walk into THE OVAL OFFICE. Toby, Sam, Josh and other staffers are waiting.
You surprised Eaton and Broderick had taken an interest in strip-mining?
I'm surprised Eaton and Broderick had taken an interest in anything.
What did I do to them during the campaign?
They want to strip-mine Big Sky?
Swallow it. Behind Sam, Josh interrupts him.
I knew you were gonna say that.
'Cause it's the right thing to do.
You mean to tell me that... [faces Josh, and begins to argue]
Excuse me, fellas, over here please.
Mr. President, it's a banking reform bill. That's the ball game. Let's not get into an intramural spitball contest over a couple of rocks that are inhabitable eight months of the year, anyway.
What Sam meant to say was that we can live without the environmental lobby.
I don't believe that is what I meant to say, Josh. What I mean to say is it'll save real people real money.
Send a signal to the banking committee that we will not be held hostage by Eaton and Broderick.

Yes, Mr. President. Tell them instead we'd much rather be held hostage by wildlife activists 'cause that's a position that always works well for us, and I think it's particularly important in the next election that we carry Montana and its three electoral votes.
I always knew the day would come when Sam would start selling off entire states. I was just hoping he'd start with Delaware.
Give me a few hours, sir. Let me talk to some people.
I don't like these people, Toby. I don't want to lose.
All right. What's next? Bartlet sits on the couch. The staffers gather round him.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Lying on his couch, Leo is reading from his clipboard. He doesn't see Bartlet open the door from the Oval Office.

Dialogues.Line: [starts to get up] No, I'm just...
Nah, I just came to see what you were doing.
Nah, you know, we had most of the night blocked for that thing, and it got cancelled so...
You should take the night off, sir.
[sits] Nah. I still got 400 pages of nonsense to read.
I don't like rattling around in that place with no one around but the butlers.
Call Abbey, get into bed, and turn on the football game.
Okay. Leo sits beside Bartlet. After a short silence, Bartlet asks his best friend a question.
No, I'm saying that's what it looks like to her right now.
But she sees what the job is.

She doesn't see what the job is, Leo. And anyone would have to see it to believe it. And even if they saw it, even if they believed it, what would it matter? She's her mother's daughter, and you made her mother cry.
You really threw some sunshine down on that one. Thank you, sir.
Well, I'm right next door all night.
Okay. He looks at Leo, and heads for his office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna stands beside Josh's office door. Mandy stands beside her. Josh is typing something in his computer and does not see Donna or Mandy.

Dialogues.Line: Can you tell her I'm not in?
No, I think the ship's pretty much sailed on that one. Josh swiftly looks at his door. He sees Donna and Mandy looking at him. Donna walks away and Mandy walks in.
Let me say this... it's a good bill.
What's more, it works for us.
No more 24 percent card interest, more savings for the average people with a tax cut, no unjustified holds on deposits--these are all phrases I can do something with.
I have no argument with that, but when they attach a rider that says they can strip-mine half a...
You never climbed a tree in your life, Josh. You don't give a damn about Big Sky.

[stands] I don't give a damn about Big Sky. I DO give a damn about hanging a sign outside the White House that says, 'Hey Republicans and Congress, feel free to slap us around anytime you want just to show that you can.'
You don't like Broderick and Eaton.
I don't like Broderick and Eaton, but that's not the point.
I think it's more the point than you think.
When you're competitive, when you're combative, you juice up the President and you know it.
Well, I'll keep that in mind.
Yeah. [to Mandy] Got to go. Josh leaves Mandy in his office. Mandy shouts when he walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: A White House staffer, LIZ, walks in Leo's office and gives him a folder.

Dialogues.Line: Oh, thanks, Liz. Liz leaves as Charlie walks in from the other side.
I got a message from Nancy Becker's office. Tomorrow's the Deputy Transportation Secretary's 50th birthday. They're having a party, and the President usually likes to send a letter.
Yeah. Tell it to someone in the Communications Office. They'll give it to one of the staffers.
Yes, sir. Charlie starts to leave, but Leo stops him.
Wait. Nancy Becker needs it tonight?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Charlie walks in the hallway looking for Sam. From the other end of the hallway, Sam calls him.

Dialogues.Line: I went to the gym, rode a bike, took a shower and shave...
...Even got my shoes shined too, you know why?
I'm going to the Beijing Opera tonight, which I imagine would be excruciating, but I'm gonna go do it anyway.
Tomorrow is the Assistant Transportation Secretary's 50th birthday, and Leo wants you to write a message for the President.
He wants me to write a birthday message for the President?
Are you sure he doesn't want someone who, you know, isn't staggeringly overqualified for the job?
[looks at watch] Ten after seven. Sam enters the COMMUNICATION'S OFFICE. He talks to his aides, and Charlie follows him.

Um, somebody? Anybody? Um, write a two-page memo on the personal story and professional accomplishments of the assistant transportation secretary. [to Charlie] I got this under control. While looking at Charlie, Sam walks in his office, but bumps himself on the wall beside his door. He looks at the door, at Charlie, and walks in his office successfully.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby is on his desk writing something. In front of him is Mandy, who tries to talk to him.

Dialogues.Line: What was the last thing I said?
The last thing you said was, 'Are you listening to me?'
I'm not the one to talk to about the Banking Bill anymore, Mandy. I have hatred in my heart.
You go ahead and pick them. Today, it's Broderick and Eaton.

Would you tell him that signing the bill, and then swallowing the bitter pill of strip-mining would not foreclose a P.R. approach that would trumpet banking reforms while at the same time, excoriating a special interest strip-mining a scam, which by the way, is what I'm happy to call it. Tell him that.
[slowly] Mandy wants you to recommend to the President that we do it her way.
Do you understand what she said?
No, but she seemed pretty confident.
I would like to talk to Josh again.
Talk to anyone you want, but in this particular room, I need to work.
You people are willing to cut your noses off to spite your faces.
Mandy, I wanted to ask you something.
You know Danny Concannon pretty well, don't you?
He's sniffing around a story about the cabinet meeting this morning, which is not a big deal, but I want him to back off.
Give him a half hour with the President.
Now, will you help me with Josh and Toby?

The President's been messed with. He beat the banking lobby, and Broderick and Eaton came back at the 11th hour and gave him a cheap clip in the knees. This is the kind of thing Josh and Toby get geared up for. You're not gonna talk them down.
You guys are idiots. Did you know that?
In our own defense, we actually do know that.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam just finished writing the birthday message. Bartlet is going through it while Sam stands watch.

Dialogues.Line: You're not a little overqualified for a birthday message?
I was happy to do it, sir.
I mean as long as you're on it, and you don't mind, why don't we take advantage of your being on it and, you know, really do a job?
It's his fiftieth birthday. Let's give it the Sam Seaborn quill. What do you think?
Of course, I'd be honored to do it sir.
Good. Take your time. Bring me back the next draft when it's ready. I really appreciate it, Sam.
My pleasure, Mr. President. SAM walks out of the door to the OUTER OVAL OFFICE. Margaret is behind a desk and notices something.
Did you get your shoes signed, Sam?
Yes, I did. Sam walks out to the HALLWAY. Behind him, Mallory, wearing a beautiful red dress and a jacket, calls him.
I'd like to say first that you look beautiful tonight, Mallory.
What would you like to say second?
Can we talk in my office for a minute?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESS ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Danny is typing something in the press table. C.J. comes in from behind sits on a chair next to him. They don't look at each other yet.

Dialogues.Line: May I discuss your story for a moment?
'Cause I really have a hard time believing that one of the cabinet officers...
The cabinet officers weren't the only people in the room.
The President would appreciate it if you wouldn't pursue this story, and to show his gratitude, he can give you thirty minutes on any subject or subjects that you like.
Well, it sounds great, but it's not enough.
I'd like you to sing a song for me.
Anybody gets fired over this, I'm gonna write about why.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam just told Mallory why he wasn't ready to go.

Dialogues.Line: Do you mind if I ask you a couple of questions?
During the campaign, you crafted a significant portion of the President's stump speech. Did you not?
The acceptance speech at the convention...
And now the President's asking you to write a birthday card?
Actually it's the Assistant Secretary of Transportation.
Oh, the Assistant Secretary of Transportation.
Sam, if you didn't want to go with me you should have said so, and if you started to chicken out, you should have called me. Mallory leaves, but Sam follows her out to the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
Shut up. They walk outside the HALLWAY.
This is something that came up, Mallory.
It's his 50th birthday. They couldn't have seen this coming for like the last fifty years?
Don't go home. Stay here. Give me a half hour and I'll come up with a new draft.
You need to write more than one draft for a birthday card?
Half hour. We'll get there by intermission. There'll be plenty of death and shrieking in the second act.
Go! Sam goes to his office and Mallory sighs.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: We're gonna want to look at a new draft by the end of the week. That's all.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby just finished up a meeting with some people. He stays in his seat in the middle of the room writing something. Josh walks in.

Dialogues.Line: I don't think it was Broderick and Eaton. I just... I don't think they have the muscle.
Honest to God, I think it was Crane.
The guy who told you that it was gonna go through, no problem.
I wouldn't say that. I'd say we've reached the end of the line, and I'm really not interested in how we got there, and I'm ready to move on.
Let's tell him to sign it.
Round's over, Josh. We did fine. [packs his things and starts to leave]
Yeah, but Crane and Broderick and Eaton?
The President's gonna need to hear something.
Suit yourself. Toby leaves Josh in the Roosevelt Room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. heads for the Oval Office. Mrs. Landingham greets her.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening, Mrs. Landingham. Is he free for a moment?
He's catching up on some reading.
Go on in. I think he's looking for company.
Thanks. C.J. opens the door to THE OVAL OFFICE. She sees Bartlet reading a stack of papers.
Good evening, Mr. President. Am I disturbing you?
When are Josh and Toby gonna come up with a solution, huh?
I want the banking bill, and I don't want to give in.
I don't want to hear about Hoynes and the cabinet meeting.
Is Danny gonna make it a thing?
What did you have to give him?
A half hour sit-down on the record.
Sir, the Vice President wasn't the one who talked.
I'm pretty sure it was the woman taking minutes.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam, seated in his chair, is thinking of something to write for a new draft of the birthday message.

Dialogues.Line: Would you come on! Mallory is behind him, waiting impatiently.
Like I'm not under enough pressure?
I don't care if it's a cupcake recipe, Mallory. I was asked to do it by the President of the United States!
I said I was asked to do it by the President of The United States!
No, you weren't. Sam, did you, by any chance, tell my father that you and I were going out tonight?
[still tries to write something] Okay, here we go. [beat] Nope! He throws his yellow pad in his desk.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is on his couch talking to Margaret, who is writing what Leo is saying.

Dialogues.Line: Findings, which by the way, did nothing to support our positions in light of the finance committee's speculation need to be referred back to the O.M.B. Yours very unhappily...
What's the President gonna do about Big Sky?
When he tells me, I'll tell you. What's next? Margaret puts down her pad and picks another one. Mallory walks in.
Don't 'hey baby' me, you addle-minded Machiavellian jerk!
Sounds like it. Margaret leaves. Leo stands and heads for his desk.
You gave him that idiot assignment on purpose!

You know what, Mal? Your mom's got a genuine beef. I widowed her the day I took over the campaign, but I don't think I've done anything to you. Working on the White House doesn't allow any flexibility in so far as leisure time as you've discovered this evening. I'm done being blamed by you for this.
So you made Sam write a birthday card?
Just my sense of humor. From the Oval Office, Bartlet comes in and heads for the door on the other side, to call on Margaret.
Margaret! [looks at Mallory] Hey, you're all dressed up.
Yes, uh, could you bring me the chief of staff's schedule for today, please?

Thank you. [looks at Mallory] You look a little glum, Mallory. Did you have plans to go out this evening with someone who had to cancel due to circumstances beyond their control because they have made a commitment to a common and higher purpose?
[points at the President] You're a coconspirator on this! Margaret comes in with a clipboard. She gives it to Bartlet and leaves.

Oh, thank you Margaret. [to Mallory] These are some of the things your father did today. [reading] He met with the director of the C.I.A., and received an intelligence briefing regarding stores of plutonium in a country which, shall we just say is not on our Christmas card list. He brokered a compromise among democrats for funding of something fairly trivial, but I can't remember quite what it was, oh yes, the U.S. Army, yes. He met with chief counsel to discuss the news hat it's possible I've broken some federal laws in the week and may have to serve from one to three years in prison after resigning my office in disgrace. [to Leo] How'd that go by the way?

Cool. He received a security briefing, a Central American briefing, and wrote a position paper, and he's been counseling me throughout the day of a bad decision I have to make. Oh, and by the way, this was a very light day.
Due respect, Mr. President... what's your point?
Uh... that's a perfectly fair question.
You know what, sir? I can take it from here.
[heads for his office, but stops] Oh, my point is... give your dad a break. He's your father.
Okay. When the President is gone, Mallory looks at her father.
Let's say you and I, we take this tickets. We'll go catch the second act? [takes her father's jacket]
Is there a way, any other way, we can fix this?
Did you hear the President tell you about my day?
[puts on jacket] Yes, by all means, let's ask Sam.
I'll me gone for a while, Margaret!
I'll be nice! I'll be nice. Leave me alone! They head out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: In his office, Sam writes something in his pad. He immediately tears it off and crumples it. He bangs his hand three times on his desk, and throws the paper away. He tries to write again.

Dialogues.Line: This is getting serious. Mallory knocks on Sam's door. Leo is behind her.
You're off the hook for opera. We would like you to come and join us for coffee. Also, my father has something he'd like to say to you.
Sam, I gave you the thing to do 'cause I was pissed you were taking, you know, blah, blah, blah.
I figured. Say, you mind if I skip the coffee? I want to nail this thing.
Forget it, Sam. Your first draft was fine.
Yeah, but I want to nail it, Leo.
Sam, the President was in on it. Your first draft is fine.
You're so exactly like him. [looks at Leo]
Well, that is the nicest thing you've ever said to me. Thank you.
[to Sam] I'll be back in an hour. Leo and Mallory leave.
Alright... Here we go... Sam smiles as he writes something in his pad again.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Nancy knocks and opens the door. Bartlet is sitting in his chair with his feet on the desk, reading something. We can see that Hoynes is waiting behind Nancy.

Dialogues.Line: [beat] Yeah, okay. Hoynes walks in. Bartlet stands up.
Good. What can I do for you?
I thought we ought to straighten out this business from this morning before it got out of hand.
C.J. already talked to Danny Concannon. I think we're fine.
I was not Concannon's source. You can believe that or not, but it is true.
Good night, John. Hoynes heads for the door.
What did I ever do to you? Where, in our past, what did I do to make you treat me this way?
What did I ever do to you except deliver the South?
You shouldn't have made me beg, John. I was asking you to be Vice President.
Due respect, Mr. President, you have just kicked my ass in a primary. I'm fifteen years younger than you. I have my career to think of.
Then don't stand there and ask the question, John. It weakened me right out of the gate. You shouldn't have made me beg. A brief silence fills the room.
I'm glad C.J. straightened things out with Danny.
Good night, John. [looks at Hoynes as he leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh rummages through the papers in his desk looking for something. Mandy is behind him.

Dialogues.Line: This bill will stop the banking lobby from getting whatever it wants, including total bank deregulation. Josh heads for Donna's desk. MANDY follows him.
Donna, who am I talking to about this?
Thank you. [heads back to his office]
You don't think it's worth giving up a piece of land?
I'm saying there's a political gain to beating the banking lobby.
There's a political cost of letting it go with the rider attached.
I know you want to win, Josh, but I've got news for you: you've won.
And when that's the best you can do, you depart the field and you call it a win.
[walks to Donna's desk] It's not a win. Donna, will you tell Leo's office that I'll have a solution for the President, very soon.
Do you have a solution for the President?
Does it look like I have a solution for the President?
[walks back to his office] Then let's assume that I don't.
I can put a best face on it, Josh. It's what I do.
You can put a best face on a turnpike collision, Mandy. I'm not moved. Mandy slams Josh's door and stands in Josh's way. Josh, surprised, looks at Mandy.
You're fighting the wrong fights, and you're doing it for the wrong reasons. That's all. Mandy opens the door and leaves. Donna walks in the office.
Donna, it's twenty minutes. I need it faster.
We're working, Josh, but honestly, the computer files are pretty antiquated.
Would you have them tell the President that I'm ready to see him in his convenience?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam is typing up the birthday message in his computer. Toby is behind him, looking at the screen.

Dialogues.Line: [stops typing] You know, I got to tell you, Toby?
Well, maybe you need a glass of wine.
Maybe you need to stop standing over my shoulder.
Why don't you let me try this?
I'm gonna nail it this time!
[to Josh] Tell him to let me write this thing, will you?
The President is empowered to designate any federal land to be a national park.
No, I want to stay here.
It's a birthday card for someone.
Let me try a crack at this.
You two need to put your heads down on your desk you know that? Josh leaves, and Sam continues typing.
Right away you're starting off bad.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is talking to Charlie, who is standing behind the couch.

Dialogues.Line: Both black and grizzly bears inhabit Glacier Park, Charlie. And hikers are told to talk or sing along the trail to keep them at bay.
If I see a grizzly bear, I'm supposed to sing to it, sir?
It's not as silly as it sounds.
Yes, Glacier Park was the tenth. We have 44 to go.
Good night, Mr. President. [gives the President's jacket to Josh and leaves]
The antiquities act. You're gonna establish Big Sky National Park. Bartlet laughs at the idea.
You understand it's a bunch of rocks, right?
I'm sure someone with your encyclopedic knowledge of the ridiculous and dork-like will be able to find a tree or a ferret that the public has a right to visit.
I've tried nature, sir. [helps Bartlet with his jacket]
Good night. He takes his bag and heads out. A Secret Service Agent opens the door for him.
[to agent] Thank you. Good night. Bartlet walks out to the PORTICO. Josh tries to run and catch up with him.
We talk about enemies more than we used to.
We talk about enemies more than we used to... I wanted to mention that.
Good night. Bartlet heads for the residence. A secret service agent whispers to the wireless mike on his wrist.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
